utterances: Chris Benson, he's a trained lawyer and a professor of African-American studies and journalism at the University of Illinois-Urbana Champaign.
Chris Benson, thank you so much for talking with us.
Thank you.
It's a pleasure.
One final note here about Newt Gingrich and presidential history, lately, the former speaker has been calling Mitt Romney the weakest front-runner in modern times.
He did so on this program a few weeks ago.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED BROADCAST)
He is the weakest front-runner in modern times despite outspending the rest of us by more than three to one.
And last week on CNN, he clarified that.
(SOUNDBITE OF NEWS PROGRAM)
The fact is Romney is probably the weakest Republican front-runner since Leonard Wood in 1920.
So Newt Gingrich raises a very, very important question.
And that is, who is Leonard Wood?
Good question.
This has probably been the best week for Leonard Wood in about the last 80 years.
That's presidential historian Michael Beschloss.
Leonard Wood was a general, very close friend of Theodore Roosevelt.
They did the Rough Riders together.
They were in the battle of San Juan Hill in Cuba.
He was also a doctor.
Wood was running for president before the 1920 Republican convention and was thought to be a shoo-in.
Was Leonard Wood among the weakest front-runners in American history?
He was in a sense because a lot of people thought he's going to be nominated.
There were four ballots.
He reached his peak and flamed out.
He finally lost the nomination to Warren Harding, the senator from Ohio, one of the worst presidents in American history.
So what Newt Gingrich is essentially saying is...
I'm Warren Harding.
...I'm going to be Harding.
I think he would consider it slander if it was said by someone else.
Michael, we actually unearthed a recording of Leonard Wood giving a speech.
This is on Americanism.
That's the theme of the speech.
Let's listen to it.
This is from 1920.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED SPEECH)
Americanization must be taken up earnestly and systematically.
America first must be stamped upon every heart.
OK.

A little bit difficult to understand, but he's talking about Americanization, that everybody needs to speak the language of the Declaration of Independence, nobody should be waving the red flag, which is a major threat to American democracy.
What kind of candidate was he?
Not a great one.
If you hear that voice, even in 1920, that's not exactly a barn-burning speech or huge personality.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED SPEECH)
...with equality of privilege and opportunity goes equality of obligation in war and in peace.
But he had been in Cuba, he had been in the Philippines, and one of the things he felt very strongly was those places should be Americanized.
There were a lot of people who felt the same way in 1920.
What happens to Leonard Wood?
Well, Harding owed him a lot, because if Wood had not been such a bad candidate, Harding would not have been president.
The result was Wood got what he really wanted, which was to be governor-general of the Philippines.
He died in 1927 but ultimately got a terrific military fort, which still exists in Missouri.
Yeah, Fort Leonard Wood.
By the late 1970s, American scientists figured out how to build a sensor that could detect moisture from space by picking up that weak signal that water vapor makes at exactly 23.8 gigahertz.
And for the last 20 years, information about what's going on at 23.8 gigahertz has been part of pretty much every weather forecast you see.
But gathering that data could get harder because 5G operates really close by.
Well, the sensors are extremely sensitive.
We're trying to measure very small quantities on the order of a trillionth of a watt.
So any emission in the band from 23.6 to 24.0, the sensors will measure some part of that.
So the question becomes, what levels of interference are tolerable?
Interference from 5G.
The Federal Communications Commission has already auctioned off the 5G frequencies right next to 24 gigahertz.
Meteorologists worry that could make it hard to detect moisture.
There will just be too much 5G communication going on.

At a congressional hearing in May, an official from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said that if 5G is deployed as currently planned in the U.S., it would take NOAA's forecasting ability back to where it was around 1980.
The wireless industry disputes that.
The claims that 5G would interfere with that are without any evidence whatsoever.
Nicholas Ludlum is the chief communications officer at CTIA, the trade association for the wireless industry.
He says, think about it like being in a car.
You know, if you're driving down the highway and there's a big line of trucks in the lane right next to you, lots of big, noisy traffic...
In this analogy, moisture is your little car and 5G is the truck traffic in the next lane.
...They're not interfering with your ability to drive down the highway.
There's something to that, perhaps.
But, you know, you have to think about maybe a wide load bumping into you.
Blackwell says the moisture sensors currently in orbit - and there are two of them for the U.S.
- are affected by noise that's nearby.
And the other concern is that 5G may not operate perfectly in its lane.
Multiple scientists told me that's a relatively common problem with other telecommunications technology.
Studies by NOAA and NASA, as well as groups in Europe and the World Meteorological Organization, have found that 5G could interfere with moisture sensing.
European regulators intend to allow a lot less 5G signal power than the FCC says it will allow here.
The wireless industry says allowing more power is important if the U.S.
wants to keep up technologically with China.
Meanwhile, the international group that oversees radio communications is scheduled to meet in the fall, and this topic will be front and center.
Rebecca Hersher, NPR News.
(SOUNDBITE OF MOKHOV'S ""SPRING EVENING"")
This is Day to Day.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
Coming up, our personal finance guru, Michelle Singletary, with answers for your questions in difficult times.
First, Nebraska's good intentions gone astray.
We're joined by Governor Dave Heineman.
Governor Heineman, welcome to Day to Day.
Well, thank you very much.
I'm looking forward to the discussion, Alex.
Well, here is what we're talking about.

Your state has passed this safe haven law a few months ago so parents who feel that they cannot care for their kids any longer are allowed to drop them at hospitals and other designated places without being charged with abandonment.
And since then, you've been mocked on national TV because it's worked out a lot differently than expected.
You're getting big kids.
People are driving over from other states.
How old are the kids that are being dropped off?
Well, most of the kids that are being dropped off are teenagers, and that certainly wasn't the intent.

No one wanted it to end up the way it has, and that's why yesterday I had a news conference with the legislative leadership, and we've agreed at the beginning of the next session that we will change it to reflect infants up to three days old.
So, a baby up to three days old you can - that's the intent of this legislation, help young parents, maybe, who are flustered and overwhelmed and feel like they might abandon their child otherwise.
Yeah.
No one wanted to see a baby in a dumpster or anywhere else, and that was the original intent.
And what happened, a senator changed the word infant to child, and that brought into play the laws of this state that said a child is up to age 18.
No one really envisioned it was going to happen.
We wanted a safe haven law.
We were the last state.
And unfortunately, people have, in some ways, you might say, taken advantage of it.
But we're going to get it corrected.
Well, let me ask you this, because a parent who is abandoning an older child or who wants to still has, you know, a pretty bad relationship with that kid, right?
Here's a state senator, Tom White, Nebraska state senator interviewed earlier for this program.
This was a couple of months ago.
Here he is.
